issues.title: add QUIC as protocol using guidance from here
issues.author: rscheff
issues.body: at the time 5033 was written, only TCP, DCCP and SCTP were around, using CC; nowadays, many more protocols use CC - with QUIC standing out as a here, probably warranting it's explicit mentioning.

comments.author: huitema
comments.body: Yes. Note that there is a bit of sadness here, because QUIC was forced to describe use of Reno in RFC 9002, while most deployments use Cubic or BBR. But the WG could not go beyond Reno... because of RFC 5033!

comments.author: huitema
comments.body:
This one seems simple, but is not. The introduction text says:
~~~
: Impact on Standard TCP, SCTP {{!RFC2960}}, and DCCP {{!RFC4340}}.
~~~
This formulation, "Impact on standard TCP", assumes that the congestion control algorithm is an integral part of the TCP specification. The situation has changed, and I think this part should be rewritten as:
~~~
: Impact on existing deployments of TCP,  SCTP {{!RFC2960}}, QUIC {{!RFC9000}} and DCCP {{!RFC4340}}.
~~~
The reference here should be RFC9000, the specification of the transport protocol, rather than RFC9002, the specification of default loss recovery and congestion control algorithms. And the text should then be modified to mention that our goal is to not wantonly disrupt existing deployments -- whether they use Reno, Cubic or BBR. The point is "don't disrupt the Internet", not "don't offend the pride of the IETF".

issues.title: Include Multi-Path (MP) CC into the scope of the document?
issues.author: rscheff
issues.body: MP variants of TCP and QUIC, as well as SCTP may see some deployments - should this document mention something aroud coupled congestion control vs. single path congestion control also?

comments.author: VMatrix1900
comments.body: Yes. But we should note that it is still in research.

comments.author: huitema
comments.body: I have mixed feelings there. If users have payed for a wireless subscription and a land line subscription, why should they not use the full capacity of both paths? I see the "selfish" case for proper scheduling, such as not sending delay sensitive traffic on a lossy path. But I don't see anything with the same moral level as "don't cause congestion" or "don't cause buffer bloat".

comments.author: ekinnear
comments.body:
Discussed at IETF 117: 
- Christian: Not enough info to make a recommendation
- Gorry: We should think about it
- Ian: Inclination is that we don't have enough information to make a recommendation
- Matt: Impact is no worse than browsers using multiple connections

comments.author: martinduke
comments.body: Gorry will take a look if he has anything constructive to write here; if so, we will run the text by the community. otherwise, close with no action.

comments.author: gorryfair
comments.body: See PR #20 for some initial text.

comments.author: huitema
comments.body:
I am really not sure that we should say much about multipath at all, besides the minimum -- making sure that any use of a path is not worse than creating a separate connection on that path.

In PR #20, Gorry is trying to separate "multipath for failover" and "multipath for load balancing". But these are only two points in the spectrum of things that can be done. For example, in various QUIC implementations, I have also seen:

* multipath of ACK -- using the lowest latency path to carry ACKs for the other paths,
* multipath of loss recovery -- resending the content of packets lost on path A on the hopefully more reliable path B,
* multipath redundancy -- sending duplicate traffic on path A and B, so the receiver can pick whichever arrives first,
* multipath redundancy with FEC -- same as above, but send FEC redundancy instead of merely duplicating traffic,
* multipath affinity -- subsets of application traffic are tied to a specific path as long as that path is available.

Not all of these have obvious congestion control consequences, but some do. For example:

* Multipath of ACK is widely implemented, and the draft multipath specifically supports it. It is particularly useful when one of the links is high bandwidth and high latency. But then, this means the multipath connection will enjoy a shorter RTT than the other connections sharing the same bottleneck, which generally results in a larger share of the capacity.

* Multipath redundancy was pioneered by the QUIC team at Ali-Baba, as a way to get lower latency when sending video streams. They do that when one of the paths is considered a bit suspect. Of course, it leads to using more bandwidth.

comments.author: gorryfair
comments.body:
This was intentional - Failover has been om the RFC series for sometime, and has been deployed. Concurrent multipath is something that has been on the edge for quite a while, but was at the other extreme - in the middle there are many things ... If you have an exhaustive list of the CC-related ones, that could perhaps be useful, I was avoiding making that list.

I note FEC has interesting interactions with CC.

comments.author: martinduke
comments.body: I wouldn't mind text that made it clear that "concurrent multipath" is a continuum of immature ideas. But Gorry is right that failover is well established and everything else involves hand-waving.

comments.author: huitema
comments.body:
Regarding FEC and CC, it depends whether FEC is below CC or above it. With TCP, it has to be below, but with QUIC it is typically above, with FEC frames being controlled by CC like datagram or Stream data frames.

I missed one interesting data point in the previous list, interactions between loss recovery and multipath scheduling.

comments.author: ekinnear
comments.body: Discussed at IETF 118: Asking for folks to take a look and comment here

issues.author: rscheff

comments.author: martinduke
comments.body: 7141 does not mention 5033, so can you be more specific?

comments.author: martinduke
comments.body: Oct 12: Pinged @rscheff to follow up

comments.body:
IIRC, it was due to rfc7141 updating rfc2914; rfc2914 is mentioned and referenced at numerous points throughout the 5033 document.

5033bis should heed the advice from 7141 around marking probabiliy taking into consideration packet sizes rather than only the packets themselves. At least this train of thought is the most likely one, which was had in my mind at the time.

comments.author: martinduke
comments.body: Editors: we suspect that this question is orthogonal to the purpose of this document; will look more carefully at the reference.

comments.author: martinduke
comments.body: It turns out that 7141 does have recommendations on response to congestion signals from the network, not just AQM recommendations (See Sec 2.3 and 2.4 for a good summary).

issues.title: What about Cubic and BBR?
issues.author: huitema
issues.body: When reading the document status section, that was my first reaction. The purpose of the document is to provide guidelines about protocols that are deemed safe for the Internet, with the assumption that wide scale deployments will only happen after approval by the IETF. With Cubic and BBR we have two examples of massive deployments without any such formal approval. In fact, discussions in the IETF would have quickly pointed out issues such as Cubic amplifying buffer bloat, or BBR having no particular guarantee of fairness, even when sharing with itself. Yet both protocols have been deployed at massive scale. What does that say about the "real" status of this document?

comments.author: NicoKos
comments.body: This is a very good point. I feel that the document could at least mention this issue.

comments.author: acbegen
comments.body: It need to acknowledge it not just mention. There are so many different types of networks and applications (or services) where some of the "hard" rules can be easily bent. Not accepting that does not change the fact.

comments.author: martinduke
comments.body: Is the intent to mention these non-IETF projects as motivation, or adjust the normative parts in some way?

issues.title: What does impact on transport protocols mean?
issues.author: huitema
issues.body: The Guidelines section asks developers of new congestion control algorithms to discuss the "Impact on Standard TCP, SCTP [[RFC2960](https://rscheff.github.io/rfc5033bis/draft-scheffenegger-congress-rfc5033bis.html#RFC2960)], and DCCP [[RFC4340](https://rscheff.github.io/rfc5033bis/draft-scheffenegger-congress-rfc5033bis.html#RFC4340)]." Maybe I am overly sensitive, but this way of discussing the issue feels dated, from a time when transport and congestion control where specified jointly. I think that ceased to be the case many years ago, for example with implementations of TCP providing choices between multiple congestion algorithms. (Indeed, DCCP itself provides a choice between two algorithms.) The Bis draft should probably present the issue differently.

comments.author: NicoKos
comments.body:
Speaking of fairness, I also wonder if there is an accurate definition for it. 
There has been activity on the topic at the IETF (on in academia) : 
https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-briscoe-tsvarea-fair-02 
https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-briscoe-tsvwg-relax-fairness-01
https://dl.acm.org/doi/abs/10.1145/3487552.3487834 

should this be discussed in the draft ?

comments.author: ekinnear
comments.body:
Discussed at IETF 117: 
- Matt: Replace fairness with freedom from starvation. Fairness only makes sense at low bandwidth.
- Christian: Not focus entirely at fairness, non-starvation goal is good.
- Gorry: Suggestion to put it in other draft, but not in this one

Overall, get rid of it all together for now

comments.author: mirjak
comments.body: In academia a next metric is to look at harm rather than fairness: https://dl.acm.org/doi/10.1145/3365609.3365855

comments.author: huitema
comments.body: That's a pretty good reference, Mirja!

comments.author: huitema
comments.body:
The reality is that Cubic has a horrific effect on the Internet: it is pretty efficient at building queues and making life terrible for others. The classic example is the parent busy on a video conference from home, and then seeing the perceived quality go down sharply because the teenager started downloading a movie...

Which means I would take "fairness with Cubic" with a huge grain of salt. As is, yes, let it run and get some bandwidth, but make sure that it gets seriously penalized, so there is an incentive to replace it by something better...

comments.author: mattmathis
comments.body:
A more serious problem is harm to tiny transactions using any protocol.   They have to rely on timeouts for loss recovery.  I suggest replacing this with absolute upper bounds on loss rates.   E..g. see:  https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-mathis-tsvwg-safecc#name-bound-steady-state-losses

Likewise for excessive standing queues, and to a lessor extent excessive CE marks.

issues.title: Wireless links are not special cases.
issues.author: huitema
issues.body: The guidelines section as discussion of "Difficult Environments", starting with "The proposed algorithms should be assessed in difficult environments such as paths containing wireless links."  Opinion may vary, but wireless links are probably now part of something between "a vast majority" and "a plurality" of the paths on the Internet.

comments.author: VMatrix1900
comments.body: I agree. Wireless serves the vast majority and are still increasing.

comments.author: martinduke
comments.body:
Gorry and Martin: wireless constraints deserve their own section. Three different phenomena to discuss
- Non-congestion loss
-  Variable bandwidth on the path
- Jitter due to media access and link-layer retransmission

issues.title: Active Queue Management was not common back then
issues.author: huitema
issues.body:
The guideline section discusses "Investigating a Range of Environments", with a focus especially on "Random Early Detection (RED) [[FJ03](https://rscheff.github.io/rfc5033bis/draft-scheffenegger-congress-rfc5033bis.html#FJ03)] and Drop-Tail." The IETF and the IRTF have produced several different proposals for Active Queue management, with somewhat different characteristics. Interestingly, there is a tension there between developing Queue Management that "plays well" with existing congestion control algorithms, and developing congestion control algorithms that "take advantage" of AQM. Not sure what to say there, but at a minimum we should develop expectations about "signals" produced by AQM (e.g., the ECN markings of L4S) and reaction by congestion control algorithms.

To go further, the could be a discussion of "honest signals", such as delays, that are very hard to "fake" in routing nodes, other signals such as ECN marks that could be produced by the network at very little cost, and packet losses that fall kind of in between. But we are not writing for the IRTF, so this could be kept brief.

comments.author: NicoKos
comments.body: On the topic of AQM, IETF published Characterization Guidelines (RFC7928) and Recommendations (RFC7567) that could be exploited for further discussions in this work.

comments.author: martinduke
comments.body:
Martin and Gorry: 
- add a reference to 7567 to AQM behavior and evaluation criteria, which is not in scope for this document
- talk about evaluating CC interaction with AQM

comments.author: martinduke
comments.body: Something like "CCs should be evaluated against AQMs that are prevalent in the internet"  -- is there a reference that provides a taxonomy?

comments.author: martinduke
comments.body:
Editors:
FQ-CoDel, PIE, L4S (RFC9332) have RFCs
Are the others that should be evaluated, and do they have available specs?

comments.author: ekinnear
comments.body:
Discussed at IETF 118: 
- Many operators are not particularly aware of AQM or these concepts in general
- Include FIFO in the list
- Also do at least an AQM "you should evaluate the scenario with FIFO queues and should also consider the impact of various common AQMs and run detailed simulations against them", while maybe name-checking a few particularly relevant ones. 
- Yes, should have criteria for this, and also should not ask people to run NxN interop matrix.
- Out of scope to _mandate_ AQM

comments.author: gorryfair
comments.body:
I suggest: Probably ought to include a suitably configured RED also.
... and not suggest ALL of these need to be checked, more encourage consider AQM and FIFO scenarios.

issues.title: Bufferbloat is now just as much a concern as congestion collapse
issues.author: huitema
issues.body: I do remember observing congestion collapse with pre-VJ TCP interacting very poorly with low bandwidth X.25 links. So, yes, don't do that. But buffer bloat, or more specifically long queuing delays, is probably now just as much a concern as congestion collapse. Today, nodes that generate traffic without paying attention to the impact on delays are arguably causing "buffer bloat collapse", i.e., rendering a shared path unusable for delay sensitive traffic. Algorithm like Reno or Cubic are major offenders, because they only slow down when packets start getting lost, and thus will effectively fill up all available buffers.

comments.author: VMatrix1900
comments.body: L4S isolates the buffer for low latency flow.

comments.author: gorryfair
comments.body:
I am not at all convinced that "Bufferbloat is now just as much a concern as congestion collapse", that seems like a very bold statement. Starving flows of capacity... and even starving control flows... is still something that we really ought to be concerned about. That said, this does not apply everywhere and most places our existing strategies have been working well.

Latency is also important!

comments.author: martinduke
comments.body:
Will add some text about the importance of latency/bufferbloat.

A difficult question: how good is good enough? Cubic is pretty bad: is a proposal that is no worse than Cubic adequate given the status quo in the internet?

comments.author: huitema
comments.body:
Cubic and Reno are both pretty bad, and I would very much like to see them replaced by something better. I very much would like to say something like "Reno and Cubic cause bufferbloat, new algorithms such as BBR do not, and the new algorithms should be preferred." I would have liked to also recommend L4S/Prague, but if the network does not provide ECN feedback L4S falls back to Reno, and that's not good. And to answer the direct question from @martinduke, "no worse than Cubic" is not an acceptable bar.

I can see different congestion control algorithms reacting to three kinds of feedback: packet losses, delay increases, and ECN marks. IMHO, modern algorithms should react to all three. There is a tricky part there because all three signals are subject to some amount of noise: we observe non-congestion losses and delay jitter on some wireless links, and with L4S we will observe some ECN marks before congestion is significant. That's why we probably need to speak about frequency, and state that congestion control algorithms should back off if they observe significant increase in the frequency of packet losses, increase of the RTT, or increase in the frequency of ECN marks.

The bufferbloat issue is particularly evident during slow-start or start-up. The good news there is that Hystart++ does a pretty good job of backing off before causing actual congestion. BBRv2 is almost there too.

issues.title: The tension between fairness and scaling
issues.author: huitema
issues.body:
One of the guidelines is "Fairness within the Alternate Congestion Control Algorithm". This a great consideration, but behind that are quite a few problems. The classic fairness evaluation derives from the equation about asymptotic behavior drawn by Matt Mathis, which end up requiring a non linear response to the frequency of a control signal such as packet loss or ECN marks. There are of course two problems. First, time scale, because many connections don't last long enough to approach asymptotic behavior. Second, scaling, as discussed for example in RFC3649. If an algorithm requires ever increasing spacing between control events to sustain larger data rates, then the control loop becomes very long, or, in the case of packet losses very noisy as "true" control events get intermixed with random losses.

In contrast, algorithms with linear response scale very well, but do not naturally provide fairness. Which is kind of a bummer, and also a research topic. I think the Bis draft will have to recognize that tension somehow, and encourage experimentation.

issues.title: Should we say something about short duration connections?
issues.author: huitema
issues.body: In the Internet, most connections never exit Slow-Start. RFC 5033 kind of explicitly focuses on the long duration connections, because at the time of writing the accepted rule was that the 10% long duration connections were were causing 90% of traffic. I don't know whether that's still true.

comments.author: VMatrix1900
comments.body: With the usage of QUIC, more short-lived connections are aggregated into a long connection.

issues.title: Keep flows desynchronized during congestion
issues.author: rscheff
issues.body: When queue saturation happens, aim to keep CC reaction desynchronized as much as possible - with tail drop this is not really possible, but AQM especially with ECN may be able to do this.

comments.author: huitema
comments.body: @rscheff should we make recommendations for AQM in this document? I don't think we can, but I may be wrong. Of course we could consider some kind of randomization by the end points, but do we have examples of implementations?

comments.author: martinduke
comments.body: Related to #7

comments.author: Ealdwulf
comments.body: There was GSP: https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-lauten-aqm-gsp-03 , but I don't know if it ever got implemented in the field

comments.author: huitema
comments.body: Matt made a good point about synchronization being caused by protocols "testing against queue full". Synchronization happens when all connections sharing the same protocol experience the same feedback signal at the same time. They indeed will if the queue has filled up completely, and all connections suddenly experience a high "packet loss" signal. But there may be other scenarios. For example, if an transmission line breaks, all connections will experience it. And if they all try to recover with the same timing, we will see a "thundering herd" when the link break is repaired.

comments.author: martinduke
comments.body:
I think I agree with @huitema's original point here. AQM design is not in scope of this document, and purely endpoint-based approaches to this problem are bleeding-edge at best.

A proposal that did this would hopefully get "bonus points" somehow, but I believe this is covered under the general heading of "how well does this proposal compete with itself?"

comments.author: martinduke
comments.body: Closing this with no action, as existing criteria cover it as describe above.

issues.title: We ought to explain the importance of starvation prevention more than the measure of fairness
issues.author: gorryfair
issues.body:
Issue possibly related to #9, but more focussed on refocus away from a fairness evaluation.

When a transport uses a path to send packets (i.e. a flow), this can impact other Internet flows (possibly from or to other endpoints) that share the capacity of any common network device or link (i.e., are multiplexed) along the path.  In turn, this can result in variation in capacity, loss, or additional latency. Transports and network layer scheduling can be designed to offer fairness between sharing flows. This comes with both strengths and weaknesses - it can reduce collateral damage to other flows; but it also can motivate the use of additional flows to gain additional network resource. 

* Transport proposals need to be evaluate and avoid inducing flow starvation to the other flows that share resources along the path they use.
* Transports proposals need to be evaluate and ensure they treat a loss of all feedback (e.g., expiry of a retransmission time out) as an indication of persistent congestion.

comments.author: martinduke
comments.body: Gorry will start with a PR that defines the terms; then we can talk about what to emphasize.

comments.author: martinduke
comments.body: Also #5 is related

issues.title: real-time congestion controls
issues.author: martinduke
issues.body: Condition (1) is concerned with the behavior with respect to Reno and, thanks to our edits, Cubic. But there are of course other congestion controls out there, both standard and non-standard, in support of real-time and other non-greedy applications. Should we mention those as a class? Namecheck some examples?

comments.author: martinduke
comments.body:
editors meeting
8836 requirements document
8867 and 8868 are test cases, but informational.

Reese: standard stuff is not widely deployed, widely deployed stuff is not standardized.
But RMCAT is new.

Maybe there aren't well-documented protocols to evaluate vs., so it's hard to require anything here.

I'll take a look, will probably have to go to the community.

comments.author: martinduke
comments.body:
Editors:
- We need to consider the interaction between real time and not-real time
- is evaluating real-time in scope? See 8836, 8867, 8868.

issues.title: Reorganize "Guidelines" and "Minimum Requirements"
issues.author: martinduke
issues.body:
The guidelines overlap in odd ways. The first one is essentially TCP-friendliness, and I guess it's implied to be talking about "normal" wired networks. Then different guidelines say the algorithm should be evaluated with all sorts of environments and/or link parameters, presumably for friendliness.

Then, in "Minimum Requirements" some of these are listed as mandatory to satisfy, and the rest as something the submitter has to report on, but the community may decide to accept even if it's bad.

There are several different concepts that are being muddled here. Alternatively, we can structure it as follows:

(A) Metrics to evaluate
- Does the new algorithm match its share of the existing bottleneck bandwith better than existing algorithms? (not underutilizing, not bufferbloating or congestion collapsing) in isolation or with multiple flows?
- Are flows using widely deployed algorithms not severely degraded by the introduction of the new algorithm?
- Is there a plausible incremental deployment plan?
- Something about short flows?

(B) Mandatory Domains: must answer positively to (A)
- Wired networks, "normal" range of BDPs
- Wireless networks, "normal" range of BDPs (loss & jitter)
- Internet-scale deployment is sufficient for this?

(C) Optional Domains: must evaluate (A) & report
- IoT
- Satellite
- Misbehaving nodes
-  Response to sudden & transient events
-  Tunnels for explicit-signal protocols
- Extreme packet reordering

comments.author: gorryfair
comments.body:
I agree we need to restructure,  I like the idea of A. I think defining heterogeneity in B is likely helpful - although we really ought to stop using "bandwidth" when we mean "capacity" - because it really confuses SDOs that actually do cap[acity v bandwidth tradeoffs:-)

I'll fight that Internet-Scale deployment is sufficient;-). That plays to the big operators, and I do not like that.

It worries me quite a lot that we target "normal BDPs" - that's not something I would welcome. It places all satellite outside normal, which again, I don't like - some satellite is definitely odd, but I'd really like to see broadband services as "normal", if nothing else, to include those people who can only use this technology.

So, main question first: can we factor the last section as different in a particular perspective, rather than "labelling" networks as optional to support? i.e. XXXX is a property, and IoT is an example, transients and abrupt capacity variation is an example of radio networks; etc.?

comments.author: huitema
comments.body:
I agree that we need a better structure. Including having actual subsections per issue, rather than the current list format.

Two points: short flows, and transient events.

Short flows are pretty much the norm, with reports of 90% of connections never going out of slow start. There is an associated problem: capacity discovery algorithm like slow start will rapidly increase the amount of data sent on a path, with a high potential for disrupting current users of that path. That's not good. There are potentials solutions such as quickly evaluating the capacity (e.g., packet pair, squirting, variants), remembering past connections (careful resume), or potentially getting input from the network (maybe something like Prague/ECN). These solutions have been explored for "special" links (satellite, deep space), but the problem is not just special links. I would like to see that discussed in the "main" section (A).

Transients are also the norm. Congestion control is a form of control algorithm, and control algorithms must absolutely deal with transients. For example, if we deal with wireless, we need to deal with "entering a tunnel" -- and exiting. We may want to deal with [some of the silliness performed in the name of energy saving](https://www.privateoctopus.com/2023/05/18/the-weird-case-of-wifi-latency-spikes.html). That should belong to the core (A), not the "weird configuration" (C).

comments.author: martinduke
comments.body: Wait to land PRs, then do this with no substantive change, then do other PRs -- this change will be editorially disruptive.

issues.title: The fixed delay hypothesis
issues.author: huitema
issues.body:
Delay based congestion control protocols are making an assumption that the observed RTT is the sum of a constant "min delay" and a variable queuing delay. This assumption may not be valid on wireless links, as delays vary when the distance between mobile endpoint and base station increases, or when changing transmission condition cause the radios to adopt different modulation and coding strategies. I suspect we also have these "variable delays" in satellite services, especially when using constellations of low orbit satellites.

The state of the art is not very good. BBR for example recognizes its dependency on accurate estimate of the min RTT, but has to resort to some kind of periodic reset if measurements of RTT kept over RTT min for 10 seconds -- which is both quite long for some apps, and quite annoying for real time apps suffering a transmission issue every ten seconds. LEDBAT++ does something similar.

I think these "variable delays" link are good candidates for "special case" links, to be mentioned in a separate section.

comments.author: gorryfair
comments.body: The variable delay part applies to most satellite broadband access using GEO also - not because of propagation usually, but more a result of radio resource sharing. It might well apply to some other technologies that use a shared capacity pool.

comments.author: martinduke
comments.body:
Min delay variation strikes me as a bit of a corner case -- perhaps it can be an optional case to evaluate.

The other piece is delay variation is not always congestion -- this is IIUC very common in wireless and is part of that mandatory case.

comments.author: gorryfair
comments.body:
In think this is something like:

An Internet Path can include simple links, where the minimum delay is the propagation delay, and any additional delay can be attributed to link buffering. In this case, a congestion controller could reduce the sending rate to the point of minimum buffering while still preserving the maximum throughput.

 An internet Path can also include complex subnetworks where the minimum delay changes over various time scales. This occurs when a subnet changes the forwarding path to optimise capacity, resilience, etc. It could also arise when a subnet uses a capacity management method where the available resource is periodically distributed among the active nodes and where a node might then have to buffer data until an assigned transmission opportunity. Variation also results when a higher priority diffserv traffic classic prompts the transmission by a lower class. In these cases, the delay varies as a function of external factors and attempting to infer congestion from an increase in the delay results in reduced throughput.

comments.author: huitema
comments.body:
The delay will also change when the wireless path between two wireless nodes becomes longer, or slower, or shorter, or faster. Or when a wireless router changes the schedule of transmission and starts polling a wireless station more often. or less often.

To give an extreme example, suppose a spacecraft flying away from earth at 12,000 km/h. Every hour, the delay will increase by 40 ms.

comments.author: gorryfair
comments.body: Sure, however that requirement is very specific to certain systems - my point is that even for fixed cabled and broadband wireless systems, the base delay changes.

comments.author: mattmathis
comments.body:
I suggest the language "non stationary minimum delay" to encompass all causes  that resemble some form of  route or path change, explicitly including LEO and mobile motion.

It doesn't really cover link layer re transmissions or delays caused by link scheduling algorithms, but these are short term variations that are more likely to be  statistically similar to IP queuing delay.   I would  use the term "hidden queues" to refer to unmanaged queues that (almost) never incur significant backlog but do occasionally cause jitter and generally can not be observed at the IP queuing layer.

issues.title: Non-standard algorithms
issues.author: martinduke
issues.body:
The text currently reads:

"The community should also consider other non-standard congestion controls known to be widely deployed,"

This is a compromise to land a mostly unrelated PR.

@gorryfair doesn't think it's fair to expect participants to test algorithms that aren't fully specified.

I would argue that if such specifications exist and the algorithm is systemically important, it absolutely should be modeled. Moreover, if the algorithm is rather loosely described, in many cases there is open source code (often in a Linux fork!) that can be tested on a host, or in simulation frameworks like ns3.

If an algorithm is a true black box, with no description besides marketing material, and no open-source code, I agree there is not much to be done. I also believe that while algorithms like this exist, they are not systemically important to the internet.

comments.author: ekinnear
comments.body:
Discussed at IETF 118: 
- There's a danger if you see a realtime flow that goes faster than a best effort flow, since realtime is usually constrained by other factors (potentially needing time to move forwards to generate more data)
- Seems hard to imagine that something not specified is able to place a burden on anybody else. If you want others to do a thing, write it down and document it. Of course, there is no protocol police: we cannot prevent people from deploying whatever they want. Can we provide a carrot for people to play by the rules: 
- Could be a SHOULD consider requirements and how to interact
- We have: 
    - Guidance for people who are writing specs that aren't yet part of the community
    - How do we evaluate those protocols
    - How do we ensure that fairness can exist with these
- Need to have a commitment from this WG to help and not just throw up new requirements for data and for those bringing new CCs to engage positively. Perhaps spelling this out clearly
- @martinduke to file issue to write something encouraging for people early on in the document
- Christian notes that separate queues between realtime and best effort are not actually a strong requirement
- To measure capacity you do need some sort of queue, or else you cannot measure

comments.author: gloinul

So just to provide the background for my question. The Reliable Multicast Transport WG (RMT) did produce two expermential congestion control specifications for multicast:

- [Wave and Equation Based Rate Control (WEBRC) Building Block RFC 3738](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/rfc3738/)

Most mulitcast deployments are done in controlled environments however, with [Automatic Multicast Tunneling] (https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/rfc7450/) multicast traffic these days have more probability to occur across links where this traffic would share bottlenecks with other unicast traffic. However, this amount of traffic is still normally bit-rate bound so it might be considered just in-elastic and consuming the bit-rate it does. 

I also want to state that I am fine with declaring multicast out of scope, but maybe some information about that there exist algorithms should be includeded in the draft. So an explicit out of scope with some background section/appendix.

issues.title: Add a section on CCA development  lifecycle
issues.author: mattmathis
issues.body:
Replace all or part of section 2, "document status" with a new section on CCA development lifecycles.   Include the following major phases and constraints.

Pilot (private evaluation)
 - Authors MUST maintain full control and the ability to withdraw all instances
 - Sources and binaries are not published outside of the author's domain
 - It includes instrumentation for data rate, loss, delay , ECN marking, etc
 - And infrastructure to harvest telemetry from all instances
 - Continuous A/B testing against legacy algorithms
 - Include methods for estimating impact on other protocols and algorithms 
 - I-D published and revised as the pilot matures

Pre-deployment and public evaluation
 - Published sources
 - Opt-in usage only
 - I-D kept up-to-date and progresses towards RFC (experimental or info status)
 - Authors maintain instrumentation, telemetry and continuous A/B testing for early adopters
 - Widespread evaluation by the broader community
   - A/B testing
   - Testing in challenging and unexpected network environments
 - Open a wiki evaluation doc
  - Conformance statement for RFC5033bis (this doc)
  - Summaries and references of external evaluations
    - Including details necessary for others to duplicate to expand on the experiments
  - If there are algorithm changes, add appropriate annotation to older reports and solicit updated results

Approval for wider deployment
 - Requires RFC publication(s) covering:
  - Algorithm spec
  - Snapshot of the evaluation wiki
  - Deployment guidelines
     - Most important question: Is it safe for unattended use by non-experts?
 - Preserve (and maintain) the pre deployment implementation as a reference for future conformance testing.
 - Evaluation wiki lives on to capture unexpected events or problems discovered later

comments.author: martinduke
comments.body:
Editors: there are several good ideas in here, but this list is very prescriptive and implies requirements that are well beyond the capabilities of many proponents.

We don't object to a rewrite of Sec 2, but these aspects would have to be toned down.

Assigning to @mattmathis to see if he can produce a PR that addresses those concerns. He is welcome to close this issue if he prefers.

comments.author: huitema
comments.body:
I think it could be summarized as "be prudent with what you deploy, or where you test." Which is indeed good practice.

But we should be careful to not appear as trying to police developers, because in reality we have zero police power. Advice is good, mandates are likely to be ignored and cause developers to ignore the document completely. Remember, nobody asked the IETF's permission before deploying Cubic...

issues.title: Define congestion collapse in terms of excess overhead.
issues.author: mattmathis

Define congestion collapse in terms of excess overhead under adverse conditions.    This is how it was defined circa 1987.

Rename the current "congestion collapse" section.

issues.title: Introduce coupling between loss recovery strategies and CC
issues.author: mattmathis
issues.body:
Although loss recovery is out of scope, some loss recovery design choices affect the suitability of some CCAs.  If we don't take this into account, we doom our relevance in constrained environments.   A partial list:
- simple RTO only
- simple fast retransmit (TCP Tahoe)
- fast retransmit with Fast recovery (New Reno)
- Go-bank-N
- Modern SACK based
In addition the presence of some tcp features has a profound impact on appropriate CCA behavior,   For example TCP without WSCALE  is sufficiently constrained to avoid many of the hazards of concern here.   It might be appropriate to greatly relax the guidelines for transports with 64kB maximum window sizes.

comments.author: huitema
comments.body: Yes. This is another way to tackle the overhead issue.

comments.author: huitema
comments.body: "The onset of congestion is very likely to cause packet losses and increase delays. Some loss recovery algorithms detect packet losses too soon and try to repeat packets that were not actually lost -- an example wold be algorithms relying on fixed timers. Other algorithms respond to the loss of one packet by sending many packets -- an example would be algorithms repeating whole messages if one of the packets carrying the message is lost. Such algorithms create additional traffic overhead during congestion periods, and thus increase the risk of congestion collapse. The Internet congestion events of the late 1980's were likely amplified by those two factors: TCP then did not properly compute retransmission timers [cite Lixia's paper] and reacted to packet losses by repeating all packets in flight, using a "Go Back N" strategy. Modern packet loss recover methods avoid these pitfalls, see [cite the RACK RFC]."

comments.author: nealcardwell
comments.body:
>  It might be appropriate to greatly relax the guidelines for transports with 64kB maximum window sizes.

I would argue against that. Even a 64KByte maximum window size can cause massive buffer bloat at the data rates of dial-up modems or LPWAN networks, which constrained/IoT devices might be using:

```
64*1024*8bits / 56kbps > 9.3 secs
```

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Low-power_wide-area_network
"The LPWAN data rate ranges from 0.3 kbit/s to 50 kbit/s per channel."

comments.author: mattmathis
comments.body: Yes, even with a constrained window, a RTT clamp should be required.

comments.author: martinduke
comments.body: Editors: @gorryfair is going to paste this text into his advice document, but this seems tangential to the purpose of 5033bis

issues.title: Ought we to mention ECN?
issues.author: gorryfair
issues.body: I'm separating AQM from ECN, although ECN relies on AQM design and deployment - ECN can be a force for good when detecting bottlenecks and latency - aka RFC 8087.

comments.author: huitema
comments.body:
Well, yes. ECN, by itself, is one of the signals that can be used by CC algorithms, together with packet loss, delay variation, and packet acks (input to bandwidth measurement). Makes sense to separate it.

However, the L4S folks have introduced a tight coupling between a very specific use of ECN in the L4S AQM, and a fine grain mandate of the expected behavior of the CCA. And I cringe each time I read their dual queue formula based on the asymptotic limit of Reno -- but not Cubic. I wish we could walk that back, or describe it in more neutral terms. With L4S, ECT(1) is a signal from the sending host to the network that CE marks should be apply at incipient congestion, instead of waiting for actual loss-generating queue buildup as in RFC 3168. Maybe that should be true even for algorithms that are not described in L4S.

Of course, we have to deal with what we have. Maybe we should just quote all the relevant RFCs, and denote the difference between ECT(1)/EC and ECT(0)/EC. Senders using ECT(1) should consider that the rate of CE marking signals the intensity of the congestion, while senders using ECT(0) should consider individual CE marks as denoting actual congestion.

comments.author: gorryfair
comments.body: I think the ECN text ought to approach with something very generic like setting ECT can provide nice properties [RFC8087], but comes with requirements for reacting to ECN-CE marking. This reaction to ECN-CE marks needs to be evaluated to ensure this conforms with the style of ECN being used. I'll make a PR.

Since the original BCP, AQM is more common and really ought to be considered in any new design - even if the design does not wish to optimise for this.

Our abstract starts:
"The IETF's standard congestion control schemes have been widely shown

issues.title: Section 2 "Document Status" needs work
issues.author: martinduke
issues.body:
Sec 2 leans heavy on the dated example of Highspeed TCP and drives pretty much everything to Experimental "until such time that the community better understands the solution space."

It says that experimental RFCs can either be those judged to be safe on the internet, or those intended for testbeds.

At this point, we probably understand enough to allow proposals to go for Proposed Standard.  The safe/testbed distinction also doesn't make sense -- we might want to standardize CCs for controlled environments, like DCTCP.

This needs a complete rewrite. It wouldn't hurt for that rewrite to also note that the IRTF is another venue, non-normatively.

comments.author: gorryfair
comments.body:
I think a rewrite would help, but I'm think that could be too radical - we still do have proposals that ought ton be EXP either until deployment experience; or until we can agree they are "safe" for more general use. That doesn't seem to be a problem to me, but we ought to allow PS also. 

I agree we ought to mention IRTF.

issues.author: martinduke
issues.body: We missed a TODO in "Wired Networks"

issues.title: Add motivation for specifying congestion control algorithms to Introduction?
issues.author: theri
issues.body:
The Introduction correctly points out the following:
> We cannot say now whether the original authors of [[RFC5033](https://github.com/ietf-wg-ccwg/rfc5033bis/issues/new#RFC5033)] expected that developers would be somehow waiting for IETF review before widely deploying a congestion control algorithm over the Internet, but the examples of Cubic and BBR teach us that deployment of new algorithms is not in fact gated by publication of the algorithm as an RFC. Nevertheless, guidelines are important, if only to remind potential inventors and developers of the multiple facets of the congestion control problem.

The above text says guidelines for specifications are important, but such guidelines only make sense if there is a specification in the first place.
So I wonder if it's worth saying a few words here about why it's useful to specify/standardize congestion control algorithms.

A few thoughts on the benefits of specifying congestion control algorithms:
- Help get a shared understanding between implementers, operators, and other interested parties of how the algorithm works and how it is expected to behave (or explicit discussion of parameters and such which can lead to differences in behavior)
- As a result of the shared understanding: Make it easier for anyone, not just the initial proponents or main implementers, to point out current issues/limitations or suggest improvements  of a spec that is still in development, and make it easier to converge such changes to a consensus behavior

There may be more benefits. 
Though I wonder how to best capture the nuance of "Some documentation or artifacts are better than nothing, but an actual spec is better than just a snapshot for documentation or artifacts".

Do people think it'll be useful to add something along these lines to the document?

comments.author: nealcardwell
comments.body:
I agree it would be great to add this to the doc, and agree that those two bullet points would be good to integrate.

Another more specific benefit that may make sense to add: due to the constraints of open source licenses, some implementors have noted that in some cases they are unable to read open source reference implementations; in such cases it is important to have a detailed spec of the algorithm that is unencumbered by open source license constraints.

comments.author: gorryfair
comments.body: I can see this would be of value to someone considering submitting a proposal. It also may help them to justify the effort in writing this down. If we can find words that work, I'd like to consider adding something on this.

comments.author: alvestrand
comments.body:
Guidelines on what to consider are good for anyone (those who design, those who implement and those who document).
The only place where guidelines could be used for enforcing something is where people wish to have congestion control algorithms published through the IETF. But that doesn't make them useless in other parts of the process.

(My friend who does CC for realtime media is developing his work through iterations of code, not iterations of documentation. Guidelines would still be useful for him.)

issues.title: Required statement in the abstract
issues.author: theri
issues.body:
Section 2 currently says:
> Each alternate congestion controller published is required to include a statement in the abstract indicating whether or not there is IETF consensus that the proposal is considered safe for use on the Internet. Each alternate congestion controller published is also required to include a statement in the abstract describing environments where the protocol is not recommended for deployment. There can be environments where the controller is deemed safe for use, but it is still is not recommended for use because it does not perform well for the user.

The document then points to [HighSpeed TCP (RFC3649)](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc3649) and [Quick-Start TCP (RFC 4782)](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc4782), published in 2003 and 2007 respectively, which both have such a statement. I noticed that [CUBIC (RFC 9438)](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9438), published in 2023, has no such statement.
I have noticed a tendency towards shorter abstracts in general, and I wonder if it really makes sense to require this statement in all cases, and risk having the requirement to be ignored.

As an alternative, 5033bis could explicitly state a "default", such as: If it's Standards Track and the abstract doesn't have an explicit statement, the assumption is that the proposal is considered safe for use on the Internet.
If it's Experimental, the default assumption is that the proposal is not considered safe for use on the Internet, and the document needs to contain more details (but remove the requirement for the details to be in the abstract).

Do people think this would be a sensible change to the document?

comments.author: gorryfair
comments.body: For mew, I do think this would be appropriate practice for a BCP to introduce. It has become quite common in preparing/doing IESG review to check that the abstract states the applicability, in same way as it notes if there is a major update to other RFCs.

comments.author: martinduke
comments.body: I don't feel strongly, but I think I agree with Gorry. We will probably mess up and publish another spec that doesn't have this text, but it would be better if we always had it.

comments.author: theri
comments.body: Ok, fine with me.

issues.title: Review inserted on behalf of M Welzl
issues.author: gorryfair
issues.body:
1. General:

In some places, a new proposed congestion control algorithm that this document addresses is repeatedly called "The alternate congestion control algorithm".
In some places, it's repeatedly called "A proposed congestion control algorithm".
In some places, it's repeatedly called "The proposal”.
In some places, it’s called “New CCs”  (only in a few places - else the abbreviation CC isn’t introduced).

I think it would be good to unify this. My suggestion: mixing “The proposal” and “A proposed congestion control algorithm” doesn’t really matter, but “The alternative congestion control algorithm” stands out - I would replace these occurrences with “The proposed congestion control algorithm”, and replace “New CCs” in the same way.

2. Section 1 Intro:
OLD:
In 2007, TCP was the dominant consumer of this work, and proposals were typically discussed in research groups, for example the Internet Congestion Control Research Group (ICCRG).
NEW:
In 2007, TCP was the dominant consumer of this work, and proposals were typically discussed in the Internet Congestion Control Research Group (ICCRG).
REASON:
I don’t remember seeing any other proposal being discussed in any other RG.
- accepted

***
3. Since RFC 5033 was published, many conditions have changed.
The set of protocols using these algorithms has spread beyond
TCP and SCTP to include DCCP, QUIC, and beyond.
***

The DCCP RFCs pre-date RFC 5033, and so I find it a bit odd to see it mentioned in this context. On the other hand, the problem that this text is about is largely related to the deployment of cc. mechanisms without first getting an OK from the IETF, and so it fits to talk about QUIC which is mostly written in user space. Similarly, it would fit to talk about the RMCAT CC’s, or LEDBAT - much more, it seems to me, than to talk about DCCP. So, I suggest to instead say the “WebRTC protocol suite” or something like that.

4. Section 3.1.2:
***
Bufferbloat [Bufferbloat] refers to the building of long queues in the network. 
***
I think the [Bufferbloat] reference should be replaced with a “proper” one with longer-term archival value, instead of pointing at the IETF blog. E.g., this:
https://ieeexplore.ieee.org/document/5755608 <https://ieeexplore.ieee.org/document/5755608>
which is also freely available: https://queue.acm.org/detail.cfm?id=2071893 <https://queue.acm.org/detail.cfm?id=2071893>

5. Section 3.2.1:
***
Evaluate the impact on TCP [RFC9293], SCTP [RFC9260], DCCP [RFC4340], and QUIC [RFC9000].
***
I would recommend to remove this. I find it odd: this is about the interaction between congestion control mechanisms, not transport protocols - why would there be a significant difference between running a mechanism against SCTP or TCP, for example? Indeed this is clarified in the next paragraph, which says: "A proposed congestion control algorithm SHOULD be evaluated when competing with standard IETF congestion control [RFC5681], [RFC9260], [RFC4340], [RFC9002], [RFC9438].”  - so why then list these protocols here?  (also: they seem strange to include as references in the sentence I mention here - instead, I would only cite RFC 5681 and RFC 9438).
It seems to me that listing the actual protocols expects a proponent of a new mechanism to carry out a huge amount of actually rather useless work.

Besides, DCCP is an odd one in this list, because evaluating the impact “on it” would mean to also evaluate against TFRC and TFRC-SP. Seriously, at this time and day? Is anyone using these controls, still, in any context?
(technically, RMCAT controls and LEDBAT would make more sense IMO, but I think it’s ok to skip them because they’re all Experimental).

6.
I would swap section 4.1 on tunnel behavior with section 4.2 on paths with Tail-drop Queues, because the latter is the more common case. No big deal, but it’s just a strange sequence IMO.

7. Section 5.7.1:
***
New CCs MUST evaluate the impact of changes in the path, and be robust
to changes in path characteristics on the interval of common Internet re-routing intervals.
***
First, I don’t think that the abbreviation “CC” has been used before. it is also later used in section 5.8 - I suggest to fix this, to be uniform.

8. Issue:

More importantly though, the beginning of Section 5 says, about the whole section, that “The community MAY allow a proposal to progress even if the criteria indicate an unsatisfactory result for these scenarios.”
This seems to collide with the “MUST” above.

9. I have the same concern about the two MUSTs in section 5.8, 
10. and there, also, we have the use of “CC”.

comments.author: gorryfair
comments.body:
A PR attempts to resolve this, 
1. - Harmonised to "proposed congestion control algorithm"
2. - New text accepted
3. - Working towards this in the PR
4. - Done

So maybe we need to be very clear about the characteristics of the oscillation that we do not want. @altanai are you thinking about something like the "saw tooth" patterns of RENO, or the similar patterns in Cubic? Or do you have some example of worse oscillations?

issues.title: Section 5 editorial comments
issues.author: gwhiteCL
issues.body:
1. The second paragraph of 5 reads:

> In general, measurements from Internet-scale deployments will not expose the properties of operation in these scenarios, as they are statistically small.

I probably agree that _some_ of the scenarios are statistically small, and may remain that way in the future, but others aren't all that statistically small even today and/or could become less small in the foreseeable future.  AQM is now reasonably widely deployed, anyone with Starlink internet sees varying delay, most Wi-Fi links exhibit periodic transient link disconnections during channel scanning, etc.  I'd suggest something like:

> In general, measurements from Internet-scale deployments may not expose the properties of operation in each these scenarios, as they are not as ubiquitous as the General Use scenarios.


2. The first paragraph of 5.7 Transient Events reads:

> The proposal SHOULD consider how the proposed congestion control algorithm would perform in the presence of transient events such as sudden onset of congestion, a routing change, or a mobility event. Routing changes, link disconnections, intermittent link connectivity, and mobility are discussed in more detail in Section 17 of [[Tools](https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-ietf-ccwg-rfc5033bis-03.html#Tools)].

The [Tools] link takes one to https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-irtf-tmrg-tools, where Section 17 provides us with: 

> 17.  Using the Tools Presented in this Document
> 
>     [To be done.]

Was this intended to be a joke?  .... Actually, I think you meant Section 16.

comments.author: gorryfair
comments.body: This is indeed long-since expired: title: Tools for the Evaluation of Simulation and Testbed Scenarios target: "https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-irtf-tmrg-tools" seriesinfo: Work in Progress date: 2007-7 author: - ins: S. Floyd - ins: E. Kohler.

issues.title: there should be a "Protection Against High Packet Loss" subsection of "Single Algorithm Behavior"
issues.author: nealcardwell
issues.body:
The "Single Algorithm Behavior" section has a "Protection Against Bufferbloat" section. That's great. That's basically saying CCs should try to keep congestive delay at reasonable levels. But I would imagine there's a consensus that we would also say that CCs should try to keep congestive packet loss rates at reasonable levels. So IMHO there should be a "Protection Against High Packet Loss" subsection of "Single Algorithm Behavior".

This is important for "Single Algorithm Behavior"  because even if a congestion control algorithm can tolerate high loss, many types of short request/response traffic do not want to pay the loss recovery performance penalty induced by high loss rates.

I can propose a pull request if there are no other volunteers.

cc: @martinduke @gorryfair

comments.author: huitema
comments.body: Yes, fair. The classic offender there is the "slow start" process of Reno (or Cubic). Last time I did measurements, it was fairly clear that this process was responsible for the bulk of packet losses experienced by short connections, and was also causing parallel connections to experience significant packet losses. In general, all CC algorithms that rely on packet losses for detecting congestion have that issue. But we have to be a bit careful to not come out as "dissing the algorithm that everybody uses".

comments.author: nealcardwell
comments.body:
FWIW I was not thinking of losses from the initial slow-start overshoot, but mainly just losses in steady state.  AFAIK for sufficiently shallow buffers all widely-deployed current algorithms (Reno, CUBIC, BBR) will have slow-start overshoot and cause high loss. IMHO that's just the BCP trade-off currently to favor rapid utilization of available bandwidth when the path properties are unknown.

I just wanted to have some text about wanting CC algorithms to avoid generating high packet loss in the steady state. So I meant to implicitly categorize Reno/CUBIC behavior in most scenarios as already meeting this requirement (except perhaps in scenarios where the fair share cwnd is low; e.g. when the fair share cwnd is 2-3 packets Reno/CUBIC do generate very high packet loss rates, like 20% or so: send 2 packets, 2 packets ACKed; send 3 packets, 2 packets ACKed and 1 packet lost; repeat; loss rate is 1 packet / 5 packets sent = 20%).

cc: @mattmathis

comments.author: huitema
comments.body: Do you have example of deployed systems that generate high packet losses, e.g., larger than Reno or Cubic? I am only aware of toy systems, like sending a file by sending a stream of packets at maximum speed, then cycle repeating all the unacked packets at maximum speed. I think some people call that the "Hilfinger protocol", but I could not find a reference -- and I believe nobody actually ships that, let alone tries to get it through the IETF.

comments.author: nealcardwell
comments.body:
> Do you have example of deployed systems that generate high packet losses, e.g., larger than Reno or Cubic?

Sure. For example, BBRv1 will generate high packet losses with multiple BBRv1 flows and a bottleneck buffer less than roughly 1.5*BDP, as has been discussed at the IETF and in papers (e.g., "Experimental evaluation of BBR congestion control": https://ieeexplore.ieee.org/document/8117540).

comments.author: huitema
comments.body: Thanks. That reference will help writing a short section.

comments.author: martinduke
comments.body: @nealcardwell @huitema you both hint you'd like to write a PR. Who's going to do it.?

reviews.author: huitema
reviews.body:
I am not sure that we have consensus there. Or more precisely, we do have consensus on the minimal statement, "A design independently needs to track the congestion state of each path,
and needs to demonstrate independent congestion control for each path being used." But I don't think we can have consensus on anything beyond that.

At one extreme, I have seen advocacy that if a connection can use multiple paths, it should refrain from using the congested paths so as to not harm other connections that can only use these congested paths. we certainly do not have consensus for that.

We may be tempted to do something about controllers setting multiple "paths" over the same underlying path, but transport implementations can also claim a larger share of an underlying path by setting more aggressive parameters in their congestion controllers -- different method, same effect.  This all falls back into the general "fairness" issue, for which we also no not have consensus beyond the minimal recommendation to not starve the competition.

Instead of focusing on fairness, I would be tempted to look at selfish motives. Suppose the connection is the sole user of the bottleneck, and somehow splits its traffic as a set of paths through that bottleneck. Does it cause unexpected effects, like maybe building larger queues or incurring larger losses?

But for a first attempt, I would trim the proposed text a lot, removing everything after "demonstrate independent congestion control for each path being used."

comments.body: *Another* use...
OK, but what does "inappropriately" mean?

I do think we can find/have consensus on some wording around concurrent multipath. (We owe it to hint why this has been on the edge of what the IETF has explored - SCTP CMT since ~2010, and other research which the IETF has not adopted.) WG chairs and AD's have consistently been wary of concurrent multipath, so we ought to indicate something, the last sentence is such as “current” statement.

Also, picking-up on your comment on "unfair" design, I agree. That was not where I saw the additional concerns for CMT: These were about avoiding harm/starvation and achieving stability. I originally used "appropriate”, only because I thought we would define that earlier, but I would be happy enough to say harm (or starvation) providing this is defined earlier. I’d love to add consideration of stability with respect to shifting traffic between multiple paths in a competitive way, if there is agreement, but have not done so yet, because that’s one stage deeper...
Happy to define inappropriate in terms of a starvation test (using "harm" metric as an example) to replace the inapproriate as a word.
Thought resolved

reviews.author: huitema
reviews.body:
Sorry for not chiming in sooner, I have been a bit overwhelmed in the last weeks.

I think we are not ready yet. See detailed comments.

comments.body:
I think this is all too long, and mixes two or three different concepts:

1) that routing change happen, and that congestion control need to be ready for such changes.

2) that transport protocols managing different paths should manage congestion independently for each path.

3) that even when paths are defined by different pairs of addresses, there is a possibility that these paths share some common congested segments.

The first consideration is not really about multipath, and in my mind should be pulled into its own subsection.

There is some consensus about "measuring the congestion for each path", by opposition to "measuring the congestion control for a bundle paths", which could cause congestion on the lowest capacity path of the bundle. This is summarized in TCPM (section 3.3.7 of RFC 8684) as "we mean that it does not take up more capacity on any one path than if it was a single path flow using only that route, so this ensures fair coexistence with single-path TCP at shared bottlenecks." There is a similar point in QUIC (Section 9.4 RFC 9000) and in the QUIC Multipath draft (Section 7.2. of draft-ietf-quic-multipath), "When the QUIC multipath extension is used, senders manage per-path congestion status as required in Section 9.4 of [QUIC-TRANSPORT]."

The third point about common segments is touching into research issues. If the different paths share a common segment, we may want to do something, but what? The easy solution is that if N path share the same segment, the effect on other users must not be worse than if N independent connections shared this segment. Which is of course a low bar. But then, detecting that paths do in fact share segments is a bit of a research issue. Yes, we have a coupled congestion control algorithm specified in RFC 6356, but this is an experimental RFC, which mean we cannot really mandate its use.
We do have a proposed standard for TCPM (RFC 8684). We also have active work on QUIC Multipath, which could very well end up approved before 5033bis. It might be better to say nothing.

THAT is a good question... maybe @Martin  for more clue on this. RFC 8684 states: "it is necessary to couple the congestion windows in use on each subflow, in order to push most traffic to uncongested links", although RFC6356 is EXP

and then MP-DCCP (draft-ietf-tsvwg-multipath-dccp) was asked to say "If, and
   when, the IETF specifies a method for concurrent usage of multiple
   paths for the general Internet, the framework specified in this
   document could be used to provide an IETF recommended method for MP-
   DCCP."
... I'll let Martin comment first.

1. is indeed generic (but p-lease talk about "forwarding" not "routing" - which includes more than a route change, I would be happy to see that appear separately. 
2. I agree is important to say something.
3. I don't agree with your proposal above. I would really like to suggest is still an issue to call-out and see what text people include in future in response.
I don't mind calling out the issue, but I don't think we can make specific recommendations.
OK, I'll try a PR, and we can always update later, if we need to.

reviews.author: martinduke
reviews.body:
I might land this as
- New CCs MUST be evaluated in environments where path characteristics change
- TODO: Say if there are standards around coupling concurrent paths (or maybe we can converge on this point soon)
- TODO: Say if there are standards for fairness at common bottlenecks.

comments.body:
We are due for a big re-org here so I would discourage worrying which section text goes into right now.

Furthermore, I think this could benefit from thinking more about test cases and less about advice for algorithm developers. So, for (1) we should definitely evaluate relative performance with path changes.

For (2) I definitely know what you both mean, but I'm having trouble thinking about how to frame this in a usable way. What if a congestion control looked at the relative state of two paths and made a path decision based on that? What if Path A and B share the same bottleneck -- isn't coupling reasonable then? What is the testable assertion here? Perhaps "vary path B  state and show that path A throughput is unchanged," but what are we hoping to gain from that? I am creeping towards the idea that we don't want to say anything about this at all, though I can certainly be persuaded otherwise.

(3) There are zero standard concurrent multipath congestion controls at this time. We may not be able to say anything, but it would certainly be nice if the community could converge on something here. Strict fairness over a  shared bottleneck sits poorly with our theme of moving away from fairness to starvation. So is it OK for an algorithm to have 3 convergent paths and thus take 3/4 of the bandwidth there?

Well, there is one standard for a *protocol* with concurrent multipath and at least two more on the way. But there are zero congestion controls, which is more to the point. So I like Gorry's statement if he applies s/multipath usage/multipath congestion control.

To answer Martin's question, yes, it is OK for an algorithm to have 3 convergent paths and thus take 3/4 of the bandwidth. To elaborate a bit:

1) the remaining connection in the 3/4th case has 1/4th of the bandwidth, so it is not "starving".

2) in a lot of cases, we have just one connection sharing the bottleneck, even with N paths. Self interest means deployments will not want to do something silly.

3) if an admin wants to ensure fairness, they should deploy an AQM that enforces it. Relying on the congestion control algorithm for that seems fragile.
Though resolved - at least enough to land something before we do the rewrite. This topic naturally will require some WG review.

I think 2 is common, but I am unsure it is helpful as a safety check. It was so hard to know if a flow from one content provider harms that of another. I think this is a more general question though - not just multipath.
Thought resolved enough to merge

reviews.body: Good enough, I'll ship it

reviews.body: I like the direction, but I think it could do with another turn on the wording.....

comments.body: I sympathise with the non-standard statement, but I would not like a pushback that I have to evaluate against something for which there is no current open specification - after trying to evaluate against some of these, I have learned this is a fool's game. Do we need to say it as a should?

should not suffer severe performance degradation... for Non-best effort. That I could not parse.

Agree to the idea, but I am not a fan of the words "severe performance degradation" unless we define this, is there a better word for harm or a need to define?
Well, "non-standard" != "not specified". Secondly, it already says "should" so I'm not sure what your objection is?

I'm comfortable with applying a "know it when I see it'" standard for severe performance degradation, but if you have other words (or a definition) I'm happy to accept it.

That last sentence is so awkward: I'm just unsure how someone would evaluate against something that's widely deployed, but not fully specified - you can't simulate it, or do any mathematical analysis only observe a specific version of the traffic, and if that changes, you might not know if the analysis is still correct?
That could sound a lot like if I deploy it, then it's fine for me to do it, don't harm me.

Would this be a way to go? "When  a new algorithm is deployed, the existing major deployments need to be considered to avoid severe performance degradation."
OK, I'm going to make this "minimal fix" and then argue about non-standard algos in another issue.

comments.body: Yes. That's a good simple statement.
Maybe we should have a separate discussion of that...
/internet/Internet/ at least here?
/bandwidth/ here is used from the computing perspective but talks about radio - where this means something subtly different - should we say capacity?
multipath routing - do you mean methods like ECMP or something else? - I was unsure.
pedantic (sorry) - the evaluation must be done and presented ... it does not much matter if this is done by the author, what matters is it is presented to the IETF/IRTF

+1 about not using bandwidth. Bandwidth in radio means the width of the frequency band that carries the modulation, and the link to data rate depends on noise level (Shannon law) and number of antenna pairs (MIMO). Capacity is less ambiguous. For any given link conditions there is a tradeoff between data rate and bit error rate, but I would still use data rate rather than capacity.

pulls.title: Define congestion collapse in terms of excess overhead.
pulls.author: mattmathis
pulls.body:
Define congestion collapse in terms of excess overhead.

Rename the prior congestion collapse section "Implement full backoff"

Closes  issue #45

comments.author: martinduke
comments.body:
Editors:
1. This metric is very interesting, but wonder if it's really a requirement for loss recovery, not congestion control (granted, these two are often intertwined). This would put it out of scope.
2. Our proposal would be to revert this, though perhaps we are misunderstanding the intent.

I remember several cases of congestion collapse in the late 80's -- we were interconnecting Ethernet networks by using X.25 virtual circuits, and things were not going well. But I would not describe the cause of the collapse as "increased overhead" -- unless we get a rather all-encompassing definition of overhead.

The immediate cause of the collapse was that excess traffic was causing queues, queues were causing the pre-1988 timers to fire, and TCP was immediately resending all the "lost" packets using a Go-back N strategy. In theory, that should only have affected the queue at a bottleneck, but in practice the excess traffic caused queues in nodes between senders and bottleneck, thus propagating the gridlock. It was nasty.

What got us out of that mess was of course Van Jacobson's congestion control algorithm, and also the work on improved TCP timers. But the principle behind that was "if the conditions are bad, nodes should reduce their traffic, not increase it."
So that might be a bug in my text: it should be all encompassing overhead, although the specifics of the text make it pretty clear.

Ar least in the X.25 networks I used, the excess traffic also caused queuing packets in nodes under flow-control/loss recovery. This made MUCH worse by delaying packets carrying routing and other network functions. You might have said this was due to the layering (transport carrying network control traffic as equals) - importnatly that part was mitigated by diffserv to prioristise network critical traffic. The buildup of traffic  was best mitigated by backoff from deadlock - increasing timers and no regenerative retransmission.

reviews.author: huitema
reviews.body: I am not sure that we have converged yet. We kind of have an agreement to update the requirement from "seek fairness" to "do not starve". Maybe we should start with a definition of what that means. Then I think we shall simplify the requirement text and make it the same for "same" and "different" algorithms.

comments.body:
I would change the title to:

1) reflect that what we need is really "do not starve"

2) align the "same algorithm" and "different algorithm" expectations.

I am not sure that we shall mandate capacity fairness, even there. It kinds of dilute the "harm and starve" message.

Also, the state of the art is murky, because few deployments can actually ensure fair sharing, especially if different flows are experiencing different RTT. Today, we have:

* Reno: flows get shares inversely proportional to their RTT.
* Cubic: lots of efforts to ensure equal shares independently of RTT, but I have no particular experience with how good they do.
* BBR: flows get share. If you wait 10 seconds, competitors will learn the actual RTT, and sharing will be a bit more fair.

Getting better shares for small RTT may be unavoidable. Hosts with short RTT will track the state of the path more closely and react faster than hosts with long RTT. It may also be what the network wants: local flows get more bandwidth; their faster reaction implies a better network utilization.
Again, not sure we should differentiate "different algorithms" and "same algorithm"
I agree on the comment about lower RTTs - i.e. shorter control loop.
Placed this in a separate section for now, so a reader won't muddle  the two things.

comments.body:
That's one way to describe Hystart. That's not necessarily what I would have written.

Fundamentally, Hystart is about trying to detect the bottleneck CWIN without incurring packet losses, by stopping exponential growth when a delay increase is detected. This is a great idea, but it turns out that it can "stop too soon" if delay increases happen that are not due to congestion. Hystart++ tries to mitigate that by not going immediately into "congestion avoidance" after the first delay increase, but instead going to a "more cautious exponential growth" . So Hystart++ is actually a bit more aggressive than the original Hystart...

Not that I have a better way to say that...

There are two separate issues:

1) Lots of short flows can be more aggressive than running many transactions on a longer duration connection. For example, you *could* do DNS over TCP by opening a separate TCP connection for each DNS transaction. That would be bad, because each transaction remains under IW10, and thus the multiple TCP connections are never regulated by congestion control.

2) In contrast, many short flows never send enough data to saturate the bottleneck, and thus always send at a rate lower than the path capacity. They are not aggressive enough.

The solution to the second issue is either to convince developers to move to a model a single connection, or to be much better at quickly ramping up single flow connections. Something like the "careful resume" work.
There's no Hystart RFC, so I thought it would be easier to skip over all that history and just say "here is something a bit different from slow start, for once"

Yes, but then BBR also has a different slow start test. It measures the bottleneck bandwidth during slow start, and stop increasing the pacing rate if the measured throughput did not increase significantly during the last 4 RTT. That, too, has the goal of "stopping exponential growth ". So maybe mention both...

This might not be the correct vector for this section. SHORT flows m- by which I mean ones with little data, do not need Hystart, Careful Resume, etc. They are short, they start, they send, they end. The next piece is where I think this ought to lead...
