comments.body:
```suggestion
The high-order criteria for any new congestion control
```

```suggestion
is that a serious scientific study of the pros and cons needs to have been done before a proposal is
```

```suggestion
Unless a congestion control
```
Honest question: Is delay variation due to "dynamic capacity assignment" meaningfully different from queueing delay.

That's a very old debate. On one hand, in CSMA systems, the mean time to wait before transmission is indeed linked to the network load. Increased delays are a sign of congestion. But that's not always the case. In mobile networks, a station may well move to a different cell. The delay may be longer, if the new base station is further away, or needs to poll more clients. The data rate may or may not be lower, depending of frequencies and bandwidth available. The old logic breaks.

The case I was thinking of was Bandwidth on Demand rather than CSMA, where capacity requests are made to an allocator and capacity is assigned from a resource pool. The two main complications are: (1) The time to respond is not related to the traffic load: it is a function of the link RTT, and the allocation interval (often related to the super frame size in the systems I know of), but also dependent on the design of the method ... these have nothing to do with the queue occupancy (2) The available capacity from the resource pool depends on what can be used by the specific system ... which may be a subset of the total resource ... and also the load on that resource by other systems, propagation conditions, implemented waveforms, etc.

In short: when there is a queue, I see dynamic capacity assignment can cause delay, but the length of the delay is a function of an external control system, not the level of congestion for the flow - i.e. the delay can be transient and have no bearing on the availability of capacity next RTT. Whereas, for a FIFO queue, the queueing delay can have a strong correlation with the availability of capacity next RTT.
Remove space, or restore the word 'proposal'?
So... let's see of what actually ought to be written for *evaluation* ?

AFAICT this is covered in the previous paragraph? I mean this one:

```
### Fairness within the Alternate Congestion Control Algorithm.

When multiple competing flows all use the same
alternate congestion control algorithm, the proposal should
explore how the capacity is shared among the competing flows.
Capacity fairness can be important when a small number of similar
flows compete to fill a bottleneck. It can however also not be useful,
```

comments.author: gorryfair
comments.body:
Wait a minute, I don't think I agree with this PR: to me: a starvation test isn't a fairness test.
To me fairness is about whether a method wisely distributes capacity between the set of flows. Often this is a long-term measurement that can be made by app, if one understands the other flows, i.e.e, once algorithms have converged. e.g. For a web client: One could in principle do this by showing that if there are N flows, a flow converges to 1/N of capacity...
Starvation on the other hand  is about the effect a flow has on a different flow. I think it may only be relevent when you have a different algorithm or type of traffic. Starvation really is much harder to evaluate in a practical measurement, because it concerns whether the flow has the effect of disrupting another flow so that it does significantly worse  (more harm) than flow that would expect. A web client typically does not know if it's CC behaviour disrupts a different multimedia transfer's timing, (unless you dig into the data for that other application (the other sharing flow), which might be with a different IP address/user.

Now I'm not sure this is so clear, in our current text, but we might perjaps need to think in terms of fairness of algorithms to traffic using the method, and harm to other traffic using other algorithms.

I think the proposed wording tries to say that TCP, SCTP and DCCP were already defined when 5033 was published, with QUIC and RMCAT added later. But it does that in an awkward way, first with the sentence about DCCP in the previous paragraph, and then with this weird punctuation here. I am not a great master of the English language, but I think we want to say that:

1) TCP was dominant then, but it was not the only transport, SCTP and DCCP were also defined.
2) TCP is still important, SCTP and DCCP are still used, but the share of the traffic carried by QUIC is increasing, while RMCAT was developed to handle congestion avoidance for RTP media.
